text: There are countless tales of massive daemonic hounds stalking the moors in search for prey.
The marshes are home to the Fimir's closest allies, where they lurk in ambush.
What horros may lie beneath the surface?
Daemonic servant creatures can be summoned from the deeps to crush the enemy.
Whenever possible, the skeletons of kings and champions slain by the Northmen are kept still adorning their priceless crowns and valuable armour.
The white-hot irons of the Dark Furnace sear symbols of the tribe and their Gods directly onto living flesh.
Norscan raiders sometimes place the rotting corpses of their dead in a ceremonial circular arrangment for display to the Gods.
In a Norscan occupation, those not enslaved will often end up burned alive as an offering to the Masters.
To draw their Gods' attentions outside of battle, Marauders duel in Blood-Groves to spill each otherâ€™s blood in deathly combat.
Permanent war paint is one way that Norscans attract the gaze of their Gods and show their devotion to slaughter.
Every clan has a small cabal of Balefiend Apprentices that are eagerly learning the dark arts from the more experienced Dirachs.
Some say the mighty Fenhulk is the result of fusing troll flesh with the detritus of the swamp, not that you would ask the Dirach unless you wanted to become part of their vile creation.
Here the Dirachs are practicing the art of creating the magical constructs, Fenbeasts, to serve their every whim.
The Marshes of Maddness stretch over huge swathes of the Badlands. Here the Fimir set their traps, capturing slaves and looting those fortunate enough to die.
Though the lowest caste of the Fimir, Shearls, cannot wield maces they can still carry clubs and crave for battle like their larger kin.
The fimir are a warrior people and only the strong survive, with mace and club they train relentlessly from the lowly Shearl to the mighty Fimm.
The Fimm are the fighting elite of the Fimir and one on one they will destroy those that dare face them.
Deep within the bog, fiendish thugs wallow in waiting until the calling of battle.
Not much more than a big hole to put the filthy slaves to work in.
The deeper the hole, the greater the reward, but also the risk. And when it's a slave's life on the line we can live with that, even if they can't...

It's not unusual to stumble upon a half-eaten, shriveled corpse of a slave. They complain we delved too greedily and too deep. That we awoke in the darkness ... shadow and flame. Good! Let its foulness join our ranks.
